columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the appropriate bid price to submit for the project.

The bid price refers to how much you are willing to pay in order to acquire a certain project or to buy a certain firm. When setting the bid price, it must be competitive and profitable at the same time which means that it should be low enough to compete with other prices but still have enough room for profit.

In order to solve this, we will first solve for the sales for each year by simply multiplying the sale price to the number of units sold per year.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=\$170 \times11,400\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,938,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 1 is $\$1,938,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=\$170 \times 13,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,295,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 2 is $\$2,295,000$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=\$170 \times 17,900\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,043,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 3 is $\$3,043,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=\$170 \times 10,400\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,768,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 4 is $\$1,768,000$

Now that we have the annual sales, we will now solve for the variable costs. It is indicated in the problem that the variable cost is $\$75$ per unit. We will then simply multiply this number by the number of units sold to get the annual variable cost.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$75 \times 11,400\\[15 pt]
&=\$855,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 1 is $\$855,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$75 \times 13,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,012,500
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 2 is $\$1,012,500$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$75 \times 17,900\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,342,500
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 3 is $\$1,342,500$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$75 \times 10,400\\[15 pt]
&=\$780,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 4 is $\$780,000$

We can then solve for the earnings before interest and tax by taking the sales and subtracting the variable costs from it.


For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$1,938,000-\$855,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,083,000
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 1 is $\$1,083,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$2,295,000-\$1,012,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,282,500
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 2 is $\$1,282,500$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$3,043,000-\$1,342,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,700,500
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 3 is $\$1,700,500$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$1,768,000-\$780,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,700,500
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 4 is $\$988,000$

To solve for the operating cash flow for each year, we will take the earnings before interest and tax then multiply it to one minus the tax rate.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 1}&=\$1,083,000 \times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$833,910
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 1 is $\$833,910$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 2}&=\$1,282,500 \times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$987,525
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 2 is $\$987,525$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 3}&=\$1,700,500 \times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,309,385
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 3 is $\$1,309,385$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 4}&=\$988,000 \times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$760,760
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 4 is $\$760,760$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\$1,083,000}{(1+0.10)^1}+\dfrac{\$987,525}{(1+0.10)^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$1,309,385}{(1+0.10)^3}+\dfrac{\$760,760}{(1+0.10)^4}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,304,051.47
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the project is $\$3,304,051.47$

Next, we will need to solve for the depreciation. In the problem, it states that we will follow a straight-line depreciation which means we will simply divide the initial investment by the number of years.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$3,100,000}{4}\\[15 pt]
&=\$775,000
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for the equipment to be used is $\$775,000$

For the after-tax salvage value, we will simply take the amount that we will sell the equipment, and multiply it by one minus the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$305,000 \times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$234,850
\end{aligned}$$

The after-tax salvage value of the equipment is $\$234,850$
For the annuity factor, we will simply use an annuity table using the time frame of $4$ years and a required return of $10\%$. We will then get the factor of $3.16987$

Simplifying the equation by combining the necessary terms, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\$100,000&=\text{Operating cash flow} \times 3.16987+\$239,247.49
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown then divide both sides by $3.16987$ to get the value for the project's operating cash flow.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\dfrac{\$100,000-\$239,247.49}{3.16987}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$43,928.45
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow of this project is $-\$43,928.45$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
-\$43,928.45&=[(\text{P}-\$75)\times4,800-\$570,000]\times(1-0.23)\\
&+0.23 \times \$775,000\\
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the expression with the variable then divide both sides by $0.77$

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{-\$43,928.45-\$178,250}{0.77}&=4,800\text{P}-\$930,000\\[15 pt]
-\$288,543.44&=4,800\text{P}-\$930,000
\end{aligned}$$

Finally, isolate the unknown then divide both sides by $4,800$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}&=\dfrac{-\$288,543.33+\$930,000}{4,800}\\[15 pt]
&=\$133.64
\end{aligned}$$

The bid price for this should be $\$133.64$ per unit.
